titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James William Fesler Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 08:30

did.unittitle: James William Fesler papers

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, reports, memoranda, research material, clippings and photographs documenting the activities of James W. Fesler, as professor of political science at Yale University, as a participant in professional associations, and as a consultant on commissions appointed by the state of Connecticut, the United States government and the United Nations. His papers on the activities of the War Production Board (1941-1946) are particularly full and include correspondence, reports, charts and photographs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Accession 1988-M-041, Box 5 (letters of recommendation) is restricted until January 1, 2055 as established by Yale Corporation regulations.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James William Fesler Papers (MS 207). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James W. Fesler was assistant to the executive secretary, War Production Board from 1941-1943, and chief of the Policy Analysis and Records Branch from 1943-1945. He served as historian of the War Production Board from 1945-1946. From 1935-1951, Fesler taught political science at the University of North Carolina, and from 1951-1979 he was a member of the department of political science at Yale University. He was also a visiting professor at the University of Minnesota and the University of California at Berkeley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The original 1965 accession covers the period from 1941 to 1956, and is related mainly to the work of James William Fesler while he served on the War Production Board as Assistant to the Executive Secretary from 1941 to 1943, Chief of the Policy Analysis and Records Branch from 1943 to 1945, and War Production Board Historian from 1945 to 1946. During this period, James Fesler was in close contact with the United States War Production Program. His papers are contained in five manuscript boxes, three of which are correspondence. In addition to correspondence between various War Production officials and other government officials, these three boxes contain memoranda, press releases, and the minutes of War Production Board meetings. The two remaining boxes pertain to the War Production Board and include confidential reports, miscellaneous material, reports from other government agencies, miscellaneous notes of James Fesler, writings of Fesler and others concerning war production, charts, photographs, printed material on war production, and the War Production Board History Project.

Later additions to the papers document Fesler's participation on the committees of various academic organizations, particularly the American Society for Public Administration (ASPA) and the American Political Science Association, his activities as a professor of political science at Yale University and his service on commissions appointed by the state of Connecticut, the United States government and the United Nations. Included are the papers of the Committee on Europe of the Comparative Administration Group of the ASPA, correspondence of the Connecticut Committee on the Structure of State Government (Files Committee), files on various Yale administrative and faculty committees and the United Nations group on Administrative Decentralization for Development (1961). Also papers relating to various United States government commissions (1936-1967) working on administrative reorganization of the federal government.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Feeler's work in behalf of the American Political Science Association, the United Nations Working Group on Administrative Decentralization for Development and the President's Committee on Administrative Management.

did.unittitle: Additional Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition consists of one box of records accumulated in connection with James W. Fesler's chairmanship of the Committee on Europe of the Comparative Administration Group. The latter was a substantially autonomous element within the American Society for Public Administration operating under two successive grants from the Ford Foundation for the decade of 1961-1971. The Europe Committee was established in the Fall of 1965 and, with its parent Group, became inactive and died in the early 1970s. The file folders and records use the acronyms "CAG" for Comparative Administration Group and "CAGE" for Comparative Administration Group— Europe.

Future interest in these records (if any) is likely to turn on this American committee's experience in establishing cross-Atlantic contacts with European scholars and—as it turned out—in promoting communication among the Europeans themselves. The Committee sponsored two international conferences, one in 1966 at Bochum, Heidelberg, and Speyer, Germany, and one in 1968 at Salzburg.

Honors
Fellow, National Academy of Public Administration
Fellow, American Association for the Advancement of Science
Dwight Waldo Award "for distinguished contributions to the professional literature of public administration," American Society for Public Administration
Bosworth Memorial Award "for sustained contribution to the field of public administration," Connecticut Chapter of the American Society for Public Administration
John Gaus Award, American Political Science Association, "to honor a lifetime of exemplary scholarship in the joint tradition of political science and public administration"
Fellow, American Academy of Arts and Sciences
